text: In women of childbearing age, use of antiepileptic drugs is a major concern balancing possible side effects on the fetus against risk from uncontrolled seizures. Use of AEDs entail teratogenic effects including intrauterine growth retardation, major congenital malformations, and developmental (neurocognitive) and behavioral issues, that need to be discussed with the patient at the time of starting the AEDs and before they plan pregnancy. Most women with epilepsy receive safe and effective treatment and have normal children, however, risks exist. The International League Against Epilepsy created a task force on women and epilepsy which published consensus recommendations to guide therapy decisions until more definitive evidence is available in the future.

text: Key physiological methods for monitoring and measuring changes during sleep include electroencephalography (EEG) of brain waves, electrooculography (EOG) of eye movements, and electromyography (EMG) of skeletal muscle activity. Simultaneous collection of these measurements is called polysomnography, and can be performed in a specialized sleep laboratory. Sleep researchers also use simplified electrocardiography (EKG) for cardiac activity and actigraphy for motor movements.
premise: Los estados y fases del sueño humano se definen según los patrones característicos que se observan mediante el electroencefalograma (EEG), el electrooculograma (EOG, una medición de los movimientos oculares) y el electromiograma de superficie (EMG, movimiento de los músculos esqueléticos). El registro de estos parámetros electrofisiológicos para definir los estados de sueño y de vigilia se denomina polisomnografía.

annotations.comment: The English version names simple "changes" and "measurements", but the Spanish version goes beyond that and talks about states and phases ("estados y fases"), which carry additional information (broader meaning).

title: Sleep
translation: The states and phases of human sleep are defined according to the characteristic patterns observed by the electroencephalogram (EEG), the electrooculogram (EOG, a measurement of eye movements) and the surface electromyogram (EMG, movement of skeletal muscles).The record of these electrophysiological parameters to define the states of sleep and vigil is called polysomnography.
translation2: The states and phases of human sleep are defined according to characteristic patterns observed by the electroencephalogram (EEG), the electrooculogram (EOG, a measurement of eye movements) and the surface electromyogram (EMG, skeletal muscle movement). The recording of these electrophysiological parameters to define sleep and awake states is called polysomnography.
translation3: Human sleep states and phases are defined by characteristic patterns seen by electroencephalogram (EEG), electrooculogram (EOG, a measurement of eye movements), and surface electromyogram (EMG, skeletal muscle movement). The recording of these electrophysiological parameters to define the states of sleep and wakefulness is called polysomnography.

text: Apollo 11 (July 16–24, 1969) was the American spaceflight that first landed humans on the Moon. Commander Neil Armstrong and lunar module pilot Buzz Aldrin landed the Apollo Lunar Module Eagle on July 20, 1969, at 20:17 UTC, and Armstrong became the first person to step onto the Moon's surface six hours and 39 minutes later, on July 21 at 02:56 UTC. Aldrin joined him 19 minutes later, and they spent about two and a quarter hours together exploring the site they had named Tranquility Base upon landing. Armstrong and Aldrin collected of lunar material to bring back to Earth as pilot Michael Collins flew the Command Module Columbia in lunar orbit, and were on the Moon's surface for 21 hours, 36 minutes before lifting off to rejoin Columbia.
premise: Apolo 11 fue la quinta misión tripulada del Programa Apolo de los Estados Unidos y la primera de la historia en lograr que un ser humano llegara a la Luna. La nave Apolo de la misión se envió al espacio el 16 de julio de 1969, realizó su alunizaje el 20 de julio de ese mismo año y al día siguiente dos astronautas (Armstrong y Aldrin) se convirtieron en los primeros en caminar sobre la superficie lunar. El Apolo11 fue impulsado por un cohete Saturno V desde la plataforma LC 39A y lanzado a las 13:32 UTC del complejo de cabo Kennedy, en Florida (EE. UU.). Oficialmente se conoció a la misión como AS-506. La misión fue un hito decisivo de la NASA contra el programa espacial de la Unión Soviética durante la carrera espacial y está considerada como uno de los momentos más significativos en la historia de la humanidad.

title: Apollo 11
translation: Apollo 11 was the fifth manned mission of the United States Apollo Program and the first in history to bring a human being to the Moon. The Apollo spacecraft of the mission was sent to space on July 16, 1969, carried out its landing on July 20 of that same year and the next day two astronauts (Armstrong and Aldrin) became the first to walk on the lunar surface. Apollo11 was powered by a Saturn V rocket from platform LC 39A and launched at 13:32 UTC of the Cape Kennedy complex in Florida (USA). Officially it was known to the mission as AS-506. The mission was a decisive milestone of NASA against the space program of the Soviet Union during the space race and is considered one of the most significant moments in the history of humanity.

text: In the early 1800s, French psychiatrist Jean-Étienne Dominique Esquirol's lypemania, one of his affective monomanias, was the first elaboration on what was to become modern depression. The basis of the current conceptualization of bipolar illness can be traced back to the 1850s. In 1850, Jean-Pierre Falret described "circular insanity" (la folie circulaire, ); the lecture was summarized in 1851 in the "Gazette des hôpitaux" ("Hospital Gazette"). Three years later, in 1854, Jules-Gabriel-François Baillarger (1809–1890) described to the French Imperial Académie Nationale de Médecine a biphasic mental illness causing recurrent oscillations between mania and melancholia, which he termed folie à double forme (, "madness in double form"). Baillarger's original paper, "De la folie à double forme," appeared in the medical journal Annales médico-psychologiques (Medico-psychological annals) in 1854.
premise: La conceptualización psiquiátrica contemporánea de la enfermedad maníaco-depresiva es usualmente fechada cerca de 1850. El 31 de enero de 1854, Jules Baillarger describió a la Academia de Medicina del Imperio Francés una enfermedad mental de dos fases que causa oscilaciones entre la manía y la depresión. Dos semanas después, el 14 de febrero, Jean-Pierre Falret presentó una descripción a la Academia de lo que era esencialmente el mismo trastorno. Esta enfermedad fue designada como folie circulaire (locura circular) por Falret, y como folie à double forme (locura de forma dual) por Baillarger .

annotations.comment:
The English version states "to the 1950s" (so, 1950-1959), whereas the Spanish version states "cerca de 1950" (near 1950), which could be a couple of years before 1950. 
The Spanish version presents Falret's contribution after Baillarger's (two weeks after on February 14th 1954), while the English version presents it as previous to it (4 years before, in 1950).
The English version doesn't clearly state that Falret's "folie circulaire" and Baillarger's "folie a double forme" are exactly the same illness, like the Spanish version does.

inferable [1]: use of "bipolar" instead of old "manic-depressive"
inferable [2]: from "usually dated close to" 1850
inferable [3]: from "was called as"

title: Bipolar disorder
translation: The contemporary psychiatric conceptualization of manic-depressive disease is usually dated around 1850. On January 31, 1854, Jules Baillarger described to the Academy of Medicine of the French Empire a two-phase mental illness that causes oscillations between mania and depression. Two weeks later, on February 14, Jean-Pierre Falret presented a description to the Academy of what was essentially the same disorder. This disease was designated as folie circaire (circular madness) by Falret, and as folie à double form (dual madness) by Baillarger.
translation2: The contemporary psychiatric conceptualization of manic-depressive illness is usually dated around 1850. On January 31, 1854, Jules Baillarger described to the Academy of Medicine of the French Empire a two-stage mental illness causing oscillations between mania and depression. Two weeks later, on February 14, Jean-Pierre Falret submitted a description to the Academy of what was essentially the same disorder. This disease was designated folie circulaire (circular madness) by Falret, and folie à double forme (dual-form madness) by Baillarger.
translation3: Contemporary psychiatric conceptualization of manic-depressive illness is usually dated to around 1850. On January 31, 1854, Jules Baillarger described to the French Empire Academy of Medicine a two-phase mental illness that causes oscillations between mania and depression. . Two weeks later, on February 14, Jean-Pierre Falret submitted a description to the Academy of what was essentially the same disorder. This disease was designated as folie circulaire (circular madness) by Falret, and as folie à double forme (madness of dual form) by Baillarger.

text: Early in Bernhardt's career, she had an affair with a Belgian nobleman, Charles-Joseph Eugène Henri Georges Lamoral de Ligne (1837–1914), son of Eugène, 8th Prince of Ligne, with whom she bore her only child, Maurice Bernhardt (1864–1928). Maurice did not become an actor, but worked for most of his life as a manager and agent for various theatres and performers, frequently managing his mother's career in her later years, but rarely with great success. Maurice and his family were usually financially dependent, in full or in part, on his mother until her death. Maurice married a Polish princess, Maria Jablonowska, of the House of Jablonowski, with whom he had two daughters: Simone, who married Edgar Gross, son of a wealthy Philadelphia soap manufacturer; and Lysiana, who married the playwright Louis Verneuil.

text: The Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus stood on the Capitoline Hill in Rome. Jupiter was worshiped there as an individual deity, and with Juno and Minerva as part of the Capitoline Triad. The building was supposedly begun by king Tarquinius Priscus, completed by the last king (Tarquinius Superbus) and inaugurated in the early days of the Roman Republic (September 13, 509 BC). It was topped with the statues of four horses drawing a quadriga, with Jupiter as charioteer. A large statue of Jupiter stood within; on festival days, its face was painted red. In (or near) this temple was the Iuppiter Lapis: the Jupiter Stone, on which oaths could be sworn.

C.). Se erigía sobre un podium alto con una escalinata de entrada en su frente. En tres de sus lados estaba probablemente flanqueado por una columnata y tenía otras dos filas de pilares dispuestos en línea con las de la fachada para formar un profundo pronao que precedía los tres cellae que iban de lado a lado a la manera etrusca, siendo la central más ancha que las otras dos.

text: The Sea of Azov is the shallowest sea in the world with an average depth of and maximum depth of ; in the bays, where silt has built up, the average depth is about . The sea bottom is also relatively flat with the depth gradually increasing from the coast to the centre. The Sea of Azov is an internal sea with passage to the Atlantic Ocean going through the Black, Marmara, Aegean and Mediterranean seas. It is connected to the Black Sea by the Strait of Kerch, which at its narrowest has a width of and a maximum depth of . The narrowness of the Kerch Strait limits the water exchange with the Black Sea. As a result, the salinity of the Sea of Azov is low; in the open sea it is 10–12 psu, about one third of the salinity of the oceans; it is even lower (2–7 psu) in the Taganrog Bay at the northeast end of the Sea. The long-term variations of salinity are within a few psu and are mostly caused by changes in humidity and precipitation.
premise: El mar de Azov es el mar más llano del mundo, con una profundidad media de tan solo 13 metros, y una profundidad máxima de solo 15,3 metros; de hecho, allí donde se depositan los sedimentos, como en el golfo de Taganrog, no llega a 1 m de profundidad. La corriente predominante es un tipo de remolino que se mueve en el sentido contrario a las agujas del reloj. En invierno puede pasar que una buena parte del mar se hiele. El nivel del agua del mar de Azov varía mucho, dependiendo del viento y del agua de los ríos que desembocan en él. En ocasiones, los vientos fuertes se llevan el agua de las orillas bajando considerablemente el nivel.

annotations.comment: Technically "silt" (cieno or limo in Spanish) is the specific kind of sediment that occurs in rivers, so it carries more information than "sediment", which is the word used in the Spanish version ("sedimento").

title: Sea of Azov
translation: The sea of Azov is the most flat sea in the world, with an average depth of only 13 meters, and a maximum depth of only 15.3 meters; in fact, where sediments are deposited, as in the Gulf of Taganrog, it does not reach 1 m deep. The predominant current is a type of swirl that moves in the opposite direction to clockwise. In winter it may happen that a good part of the sea cools. The water level of the Sea of Azov varies greatly, depending on the wind and water of the rivers that flow into it. At times, strong winds take the water from the banks down considerably the level.
translation2: The Azov Sea is the flattest sea in the world, with an average depth of only 13 meters, and a maximum depth of only 15.3 meters; in fact, where sediments are deposited, such as in the Taganrog Gulf, it is less than 1 m deep. The water level of the Sea of Azov varies greatly, depending on the wind and the water of the rivers that flow into it. Occasionally, strong winds carry the water away from the shores, lowering the water level considerably.

Sometimes, strong winds carry the water from the shores, lowering the level considerably.

text: Starting in the 1950s, many species have been introduced to Lake Victoria where they have become invasive and a prime reason for the extinction of many endemic haplochromine cichlids. Among the introductions are several tilapias: redbreast (Coptodon rendalli), redbelly (C. zillii), Nile (Oreochromis niloticus) and blue-spotted tilapias (O. leucostictus). . Although these have contributed to the extinction of native fish by causing significant changes to the ecosystem, outcompeted natives and (in the case of the Nile tilapia) possibly hybridized with the highly threatened native tilapias, the most infamous introduction was the large and highly predatory Nile perch (Lates niloticus).
premise: Desde la introducción de la perca del Nilo (Lates niloticus) en la década de 1960, más de doscientas especies endémicas de Haplochromis, además de otras especies, han desaparecido y otras están en grave peligro. La perca del Nilo, pez de gran tamaño y de enorme voracidad, acabó de esta forma con la fuente de pesca tradicional de los habitantes de las orillas de lago durante miles de años. Sin embargo, no se puede achacar sólo a la depredación de la perca del Nilo la desaparición de la biodiversidad del lago, sino a una combinación con la eutrofización del lago, con la consecuente disminución en la concentración de oxígeno disuelto en el agua, y la pérdida de hábitat natural.

EV highlights the responsibility of the perch, while SV is taking away from it. 
"many endemic" is inferable from SV's "más de doscientas especies endémicas" (more than two hundred endemic species). Although, one could argue that "many", in this case, is an understatement (connotation difference?)

title: Lake Victoria
translation: Since the introduction of the Nile perch (Lates niloticus) in the 1960s, more than two hundred endemic species of Haplochromis, in addition to other species, have disappeared and others are in grave danger. The Nile perch, a large fish of enormous voracity, thus ended with the traditional fishing source of the inhabitants of the lakeshores for thousands of years. However, it is not only to the predation of the Nile perch the disappearance of the biodiversity of the lake, but to a combination with the eutrophication of the lake, with the consequent decrease in the concentration of dissolved oxygen in the water, and the loss of natural habitat.
translation2: Since the introduction of the Nile perch (Lates niloticus) in the 1960s, more than two hundred endemic Haplochromis species, as well as other species, have disappeared and others are seriously endangered. The Nile perch, a large and extremely voracious fish, thus wiped out the traditional source of fish for the lake shore dwellers for thousands of years. However, the disappearance of the lake's biodiversity cannot be blamed solely on the predation of the Nile perch, but rather on a combination with the eutrophication of the lake, with the consequent decrease in the concentration of dissolved oxygen in the water, and the loss of natural habitat.
translation3: Since the introduction of the Nile perch (Lates niloticus) in the 1960s, more than two hundred endemic Haplochromis species, as well as other species, have disappeared and others are seriously endangered. The Nile perch, a large and voracious fish, thus ended the traditional source of fishing for the inhabitants of the lake shores for thousands of years. text: The Wellcome Trust is a charitable foundation focused on health research based in London, in the United Kingdom. It was established in 1936 with legacies from the pharmaceutical magnate Henry Wellcome (founder of one of the predecessors of GlaxoSmithKline) to fund research to improve human and animal health. The aim of the Trust is to "support science to solve the urgent health challenges facing everyone." It had a financial endowment of £29.1 billion in 2020, making it the fourth wealthiest charitable foundation in the world. In 2012, the Wellcome Trust was described by the Financial Times as the United Kingdom's largest provider of non-governmental funding for scientific research, and one of the largest providers in the world. According to their annual report, the Wellcome Trust spent GBP £1.1Bn on charitable activities across their 2019/2020 financial year. According to the OECD, the Wellcome Trust's financing for 2019 development increased by 22% to US$327 million.
premise: La Wellcome Trust es una organización benéfica de investigación biomédica con sede en Londres, Reino Unido. Fue establecida en 1936 con legados del magnate farmacéutico Sir Henry Wellcome para financiar la investigación para mejorar la salud humana y animal. El objetivo de la Fundación es "lograr mejoras extraordinarias en la salud apoyando a las mentes más brillantes", y además de financiar la investigación biomédica, apoya la comprensión pública de la ciencia. Tiene una dotación de 23.200 millones de euros (2017), lo que la convierte en la segunda fundación benéfica más rica del mundo, después de la Fundación Bill y Melinda Gates.

text: Most of the major sources on Pythagoras's life are from the Roman period, by which point, according to the German classicist Walter Burkert, "the history of Pythagoreanism was already... the laborious reconstruction of something lost and gone." Three ancient biographies of Pythagoras have survived from late antiquity, all of which are filled primarily with myths and legends. The earliest and most respectable of these is the one from Diogenes Laërtius's Lives and Opinions of Eminent Philosophers. The two later biographies were written by the Neoplatonist philosophers Porphyry and Iamblichus and were partially intended as polemics against the rise of Christianity. The later sources are much lengthier than the earlier ones, and even more fantastic in their descriptions of Pythagoras's achievements. Porphyry and Iamblichus used material from the lost writings of Aristotle's disciples and material taken from these sources is generally considered to be the most reliable.
premise: La más extensa, detallada e influyente obra sobre la vida de Pitágoras y su pensamiento data del , es decir, unos 800 años después de su muerte. Diógenes Laercio (ca. 200-250) y Porfirio (ca. 234-305) escribieron dos Vidas de Pitágoras, y Jámblico (ca. 245-325) Sobre la vida pitagórica. Estas biografías son, con algunas excepciones,Jenófanes, Heráclito, Heródoto, Platón, Aristóteles e Isócrates. Pertenecen a una época en que la figura de Pitágoras era vista de modo distorsionado y se basan, a su vez, en fuentes extraviadas, algunas de las cuales son de marcada tendencia neopitagórica y deliberadamente orientadas a ensalzar a Pitágoras, presentándolo como el origen de toda la verdad filosófica, cuyas ideas habrían sido plagiadas por Platón, Aristóteles y todos los filósofos posteriores.

text: Escalating tensions caused Chinese to turn against "foreign devils" who scrambled for power in the late 19th century. title: Ernst Haeckel
translation: Ernst Haeckel was a fervent evolutionist. His ideas in this regard were collected in 1866 in his Generelle Morphologie der Organismen (General Morphology of Organisms), whose second volume devoted to Charles Darwin, Wolfgang Goethe and Jean-Baptiste Lamarck. However, although Haeckel was a great advocate of the idea of natural selection, he actually ignored the role of chance in Darwinist theory. His evolutionism accepted many of Lamarck’s and Naturphilosophie’s ideas. Radically progressive, Haeckel argued that evolution was directed towards a progressive complexity that would have man as its ultimate goal. Haeckel was, moreover, radically materialist and monist and considered evolution as one of the best proofs of such philosophy.

title: July
translation: In the Gregorian calendar, July is the seventh month of the year and has 31 days. Originally this month was the fifth of the early Roman calendar and its name was Quintilis. At first, it had 36 days but was changed to 31 by the king Romulus and reduced to 30 by the second king of Rome Numa, finally the 31 that it currently has by the Roman dictator Julius Caesar. In homage to it (Iulius Caesar, in Latin) that had been born on the 13th of the month, it was renamed by Marco Antonio to "Iulius," from where it derives "July".

Originally, it had 36 days but was changed to 31 by King Romulus and reduced to 30 by the second king of Rome, Numa, and finally to the current 31 by the Roman dictator Julius Caesar. In tribute to him (Iulius Caesar, in Latin) who was born on the 13th day of the month, it was renamed by Mark Antony to "Iulius," from which "Julius" is derived.

text: In plains and mountain zebras, foals are cared for mostly by their mothers, but if threatened by pack-hunting hyenas and dogs, the entire group works together to protect all the young. The group forms a protective front with the foals in the centre, and the stallion will rush at predators that come too close. In Grévy's zebras, young stay in "kindergartens" when their mothers leave for water. These groups are tended to by the territorial male. A stallion may look after a foal in his territory to ensure that the mother stays, though it may not be his. By contrast, plains zebra stallions are generally intolerant of foals that are not theirs and may practice infanticide and feticide via violence to the pregnant mare.
premise: En el caso de las cebras de montaña y las cebras comunes, los potros son protegidos por su madre, así como por el macho y las otras yeguas del grupo. En cambio, los potros de cebra de Grévy sólo tienen a su madre como protectora habitual, pues, como se ha dicho más arriba, los grupos de esta especie se suelen dispersar después de unos cuantos meses. La protección de los potros es especialmente relevante para estos animales, pues las crías son una presa fácil para los predadores y la mitad de ellas no sobreviven al primer año de vida a pesar de los esfuerzos de su madre y del macho del grupo. Otro de los peligros que corren los potros es que se han observado infanticidios y feticidios entre las cebras, a pesar de que únicamente se ha observado este comportamiento en ejemplares en cautividad.

text: After a first PE, the search for secondary causes is usually brief. Only when a second PE occurs, and especially when this happens while still under anticoagulant therapy, a further search for underlying conditions is undertaken. This will include testing ("thrombophilia screen") for Factor V Leiden mutation, antiphospholipid antibodies, protein C and S and antithrombin levels, and later prothrombin mutation, MTHFR mutation, Factor VIII concentration and rarer inherited coagulation abnormalities.

Esto incluirá pruebas ("cribado de trombofilia") para la mutación del factorV Leiden, anticuerpos antifosfolípidos, proteínaC y S y niveles de antitrombina, y más tarde mutación de protrombina, mutación de MTHFR, concentración de factorVIII y anomalías de coagulación hereditarias más raras.

adicional (additional) / further: Since it's a continuation of the first search (not an entirely different second search), I would use the word "extendida" (extended) rather than "adicional" (additional).

text: In Laughter: An Essay on the Meaning of the Comic, French philosopher Henri Bergson, renowned for his philosophical studies on materiality, memory, life and consciousness, tries to determine the laws of the comic and to understand the fundamental causes of comic situations. His method consists in determining the causes of the comic instead of analyzing its effects. He also deals with laughter in relation to human life, collective imagination and art, to have a better knowledge of society. One of the theories of the essay is that laughter, as a collective activity, has a social and moral role, in forcing people to eliminate their vices. It is a factor of uniformity of behaviours, as it condemns ludicrous and eccentric behaviours.

También la define como un fenómeno grupal, y por lo tanto con funciones sociales. Peter Berger, en su libro Risa redentora (1997), declara no estar de acuerdo con el pensamiento de Bergson acerca del carácter social de la risa. En sus propias palabras: «esto es discutible, sin duda también existe la diversión solitaria». Incluso en la risa en soledad, siempre existe un elemento humano —o, al menos, de un ser vivo animado— directa o indirectamente relacionado con el suceso desencadenante. Un aspecto destacable de su pensamiento es que considera que lo cómico aparece cuando se reprimen otras emociones, como el odio, o la compasión.

title: Laughter
translation: At the end of the, Henri Bergson recognized laughter as fundamentally social. He defines laughter as an exclusively human phenomenon: although other animals may manifest symptoms similar to laughter, only human beings actually laugh. He also defines it as a group phenomenon, and therefore with social functions. Peter Berger, in his book Risa redentora (1997), declares that he does not agree with Bergson’s thinking about the social character of laughter. In his own words: “this is debatable, surely there is also solitary fun.” Even in laughter in solitude, there is always a human element — or at least a lively living being — directly or indirectly related to the triggering event. One notable aspect of his thought is that he considers that comics appear when other emotions, such as hatred, or compassion, are repressed.
translation2: At the end of the , Henri Bergson recognized laughter as fundamentally social. He defines laughter as an exclusively human phenomenon: although other animals may manifest laughter-like symptoms, only human beings actually laugh. He also defines it as a group phenomenon, and therefore with social functions. Peter Berger, in his book Redemptive Laughter (1997), states that he disagrees with Bergson's thinking about the social character of laughter. In his own words: "this is debatable, there is undoubtedly also solitary amusement". Even in solitary laughter, there is always a human element - or, at least, of an animate living being - directly or indirectly related to the triggering event. A remarkable aspect of his thinking is that he considers that the comic appears when other emotions, such as hatred or compassion, are repressed.
translation3: At the end of the , Henri Bergson recognized laughter as fundamentally social. He defines laughter as a uniquely human phenomenon: although other animals may display symptoms similar to laughter, only humans actually laugh. Even in lonely laughter, there is always a human element—or at least an animated living being—directly or indirectly related to the triggering event. A remarkable aspect of his thinking is that he considers that the comic appears when other emotions are repressed, such as hatred or compassion.

text: Incineration is a disposal method in which solid organic wastes are subjected to combustion so as to convert them into residue and gaseous products. text: The spleen is underneath the left part of the diaphragm, and has a smooth, convex surface that faces the diaphragm. It is underneath the ninth, tenth, and eleventh ribs. The other side of the spleen is divided by a ridge into two regions: an anterior gastric portion, and a posterior renal portion. The gastric surface is directed forward, upward, and toward the middle, is broad and concave, and is in contact with the posterior wall of the stomach. Below this it is in contact with the tail of the pancreas. The renal surface is directed medialward and downward. It is somewhat flattened, considerably narrower than the gastric surface, and is in relation with the upper part of the anterior surface of the left kidney and occasionally with the left adrenal gland.

El bazo está sujeto por bandas fibrosas unidas al peritoneo (la membrana que reviste la cavidad abdominal). Se relaciona posteriormente con las 9°, 10° y la 11° costillas izquierdas. Reposa sobre la flexura cólica izquierda o ángulo esplénico del colon, unido a este por el ligamento esplenomesocólico, y hace contacto con el estómago por el epiplón gastroesplénico así como con el riñón izquierdo.

text: The word utility is used to mean general well-being or happiness, and Mill's view is that utility is the consequence of a good action. Utility, within the context of utilitarianism, refers to people performing actions for social utility. With social utility, he means the well-being of many people. Mill's explanation of the concept of utility in his work, Utilitarianism, is that people really do desire happiness, and since each individual desires their own happiness, it must follow that all of us desire the happiness of everyone, contributing to a larger social utility. Thus, an action that results in the greatest pleasure for the utility of society is the best action, or as Jeremy Bentham, the founder of early Utilitarianism put it, as the greatest happiness of the greatest number.
premise: La "utilidad" se define de varias maneras, generalmente en términos del bienestar de los seres humanos. Bentham la describió como la suma de todo placer que resulta de una acción, menos el sufrimiento de cualquier persona involucrada en dicha acción. En la economía neoclásica, se llama utilidad a la satisfacción de preferencias, mientras que en la filosofía moral, es sinónimo de felicidad, sea cual sea el modo en el que esta se entienda. Esta doctrina ética a veces es resumida como "el máximo bienestar para el máximo número".

title: Utilitarianism
translation: The "utility" is defined in several ways, generally in terms of the well-being of human beings. Bentham described it as the sum of all pleasure resulting from an action, except the suffering of any person involved in such action. In the neoclassical economy, it is called utility to preference satisfaction, while in moral philosophy, it is synonymous with happiness, whatever way it is understood. This ethical doctrine is sometimes summed up as "the maximum well-being for the maximum number."

text: The symptoms of diphtheria usually begin two to seven days after infection. They include fever of 38 °C (100.4 °F) or above; chills; fatigue; bluish skin coloration (cyanosis); sore throat; hoarseness; cough; headache; difficulty swallowing; painful swallowing; difficulty breathing; rapid breathing; foul-smelling and bloodstained nasal discharge; and lymphadenopathy. Within two to three days, diphtheria may destroy healthy tissues in the respiratory system. The dead tissue forms a thick, gray coating that can build up in the throat or nose. This thick gray coating is called a "pseudomembrane". It can cover tissues in the nose, tonsils, voice box, and throat, making it very hard to breathe and swallow. Symptoms can also include cardiac arrhythmias, myocarditis, and cranial and peripheral nerve palsies.
premise: Existen dos cuadros clásicos de difteria: uno en la nariz y la garganta y otro en la piel. Además, se puede formar una membrana en la garganta. Las lesiones de la piel pueden ser dolorosas, de aspecto hinchado y enrojecido. También se reconocen con menor frecuencia cuadros iniciales de infección cutánea, vaginal, de conjuntivas oculares u oídos. Los síntomas suelen aparecer a los 3 a 9 días. Si no aparecen antes o después, se debe acudir a un hospital entre 24 a 48 horas después del contagio.

title: Diphtheria
translation: There are two classic symptoms of diphtheria: one in the nose and throat and the other in the skin. The main symptoms are sore throat, mild increase in body temperature, and swollen lymph nodes (lymph nodes) in the neck. In addition, a membrane may form in the throat. Skin lesions may be painful, swollen and reddened. Initial signs of skin, vaginal, eye conjunctive, or ear infection are also less commonly recognized. Symptoms usually appear at 3 to 9 days. If they do not appear before or after the infection, they should be referred to a hospital 24 to 48 hours after the infection.
translation2: There are two classic diphtheria cases: one in the nose and throat and one in the skin. The main symptoms are a sore throat, a slight increase in body temperature and swollen lymph nodes (lymph nodes) in the neck. In addition, a membrane may form in the throat. Skin lesions may be painful, swollen and reddened in appearance. Initial skin, vaginal, conjunctival, ocular conjunctival or ear infections are also less commonly recognized. Symptoms usually appear after 3 to 9 days. If they do not appear earlier or later, a hospital visit should be made within 24 to 48 hours after infection.
translation3: There are two classic pictures of diphtheria: one in the nose and throat and the other on the skin. The main symptoms are a sore throat, a slight increase in body temperature, and swollen lymph nodes (lymph nodes) in the neck. Also, a membrane can form in the throat. Skin lesions can be painful, swollen, and red in appearance. Initial symptoms of skin, vaginal, ocular conjunctivae, or ear infections are also recognized less frequently. Symptoms usually appear within 3 to 9 days. If they do not appear before or after, you should go to a hospital between 24 to 48 hours after infection.

text: Distinct from a disposition to believe that things will work out, there is a philosophical idea that, perhaps in ways that may not be fully comprehended, the present moment is in an optimum state. This view that all of nature - past, present, and future - operates by laws of optimization along the lines of Hamilton's principle in the realm of physics is countered by views such as idealism, realism, and philosophical pessimism. Philosophers often link the concept of optimism with the name of Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, who held that we live in the best of all possible worlds (le meilleur des mondes possibles), or that God created a physical universe that applies the laws of physics. The concept was also reflected in an aspect of Francois-Marie Arouet de Voltaire's early philosophy, one that was based on Isaac Newton's view that described a divinely ordered human condition. This philosophy would also later emerge in Alexander Pope's Essay on Man.

Una postura parecida es sostenida con distintos matices por los filósofos William Godwin, Ralph Waldo Emerson y Friedrich Nietzsche. Por otra parte, el espíritu de algunos movimientos espirituales, como el Renacimiento y la Ilustración, fue identificado como optimista y lleno de fe en el hombre y sus posibilidades, frente a épocas opuestas y pesimistas como la Edad Media y el Barroco.

title: Parody
translation: According to Aristotle ( ), Hegemon de Tassos was the inventor of a kind of parody; slightly altering the writing of known poems, he transformed the sublime into ridiculous. In ancient Greek literature, a parody was a narrative poem that imitated the style and prosedia of epics "but that dealt with light, satirical or mock-heroic themes." Indeed, the components of the Greek word are  for "on the side, against, against" and  oide "song". Thus, the original Greek word  parody has sometimes been taken to mean "contraction", an imitation that contrasts with the original. Oxford English Dictionary, for example, defines parody as the imitation "turned as to produce a ridiculous effect." Since par- also has the non-antagogic meaning of the side, "there is nothing in parody that makes necessary the inclusion of a concept of ridicule."

Indeed, the components of the Greek word are παρά for "beside, against, against" and ᾠδή oide "song." Thus, the original Greek word παρῳδία parody has sometimes been taken to mean "counter-singing," an imitation set against the original. The Oxford English Dictionary, for example, defines parody as imitation "turned as if to produce a ridiculous effect." Since par- also has the non-antagonistic meaning of beside, "there is nothing in parody that makes it necessary to include a concept of ridicule."
translation3: According to Aristotle ( ), Hegemón de Thasos was the inventor of a type of parody; by slightly altering the wording of well-known poems, he transformed the sublime into the ridiculous. In ancient Greek literature, a parody was a narrative poem that imitated the style and prosody of epics "but dealt with light, satirical, or mock-heroic themes." Indeed, the components of the Greek word are παρά for "beside, against, against" and ᾠδή oide "song". Thus the original Greek word παρῳδία parodia has sometimes been taken to mean "counter-song", an imitation set against the original. The Oxford English Dictionary, for example, defines parody as imitation "twisted so as to produce a ridiculous effect". Since par- also has the non-antagonistic meaning next to it, "there is nothing in parody that necessitates the inclusion of a concept of ridiculousness".

text: Herat is first recorded in ancient times, but its precise date of foundation is unknown. Under the Persian Achaemenid Empire (550–330 BC), the surrounding district was known by the Old Persian name of Haraiva (𐏃𐎼𐎡𐎺), and in classical sources, the region was correspondingly known as Areia (Aria). In the Zoroastrian collection of Avesta, the district is referred as Haroiva. The name of the district and its principal town is a derivative from that of the local river, the Herey River (from Old Iranian Harayu, meaning "with velocity"), which goes through the district and ends south of Herat. Herey is mentioned in Sanskrit as a yellow or golden color equivalent to Persian "Zard" meaning Gold (yellow). The naming of a region and its principal town after the main river is a common feature in this part of the world— compare the adjoining districts/rivers/towns of Arachosia and Bactria.

En el Avesta zoroastriano, la ciudad es mencionada como Haroiva. El nombre del distrito y su ciudad principal deriva del río principal de la región, el Hari Rud (antiguo persa harayu, ‘con velocidad’), el cual cruza el distrito y pasa justo al sur (5 km) de la moderna Herāt. El nombrar una región y su principal ciudad por su río principal es una característica muy común en esta parte del mundo.

text: Old age is the range of ages nearing and surpassing the life expectancy of human beings; it is the end of the human life cycle. Terms, some of them euphemisms, for people at this age include old people, the elderly (worldwide usage), OAPs (British for Old Age Pensioner), seniors, senior citizens (American), older adults (in the social ), and elders (many cultures).

title: Fennel
